runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a boy who wants to support a
, or an organization he believes in. Explain that a
is a place where people can get free food. Ask students to predict what the boys idea might be.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a group or organization that helps people or animals in need.
might give food to help animals in a shelter.
: How could someone raise money for a
that helps people in their community?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the main character. (Paul)
What is Pauls plan to help the food bank? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How is a food bank a
? How does a food bank make a difference in a community?
would you be willing to support? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue for a story.
Explain that a coral reef is a large structure under the water made up of sea creatures called corals. Ask students to point to the coral reef on page 8.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
the plants and animals that live there.
: What can happen to plants and animals whose homes are
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells where divers go to see coral reefs. (into the water)
What is the connection between polyps and coral reefs? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the worlds coral reefs being
mean? How can regrowing coral in nurseries help coral reefs that have been damaged?
Why do you think the author included the subtitle A Call to Action? How does the author encourage readers to take action?
What other questions do you have about coral reefs? How could you find answers to them?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with variant vowel
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 1, 2, and 6. Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence. Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your phrasing.

Read the title. Explain that this is a poem. Point out that the text is formatted in short lines in groups of four instead of paragraphs. Ask students to listen for words that rhyme, or end with the same sounds.
For the first reading, have students echoread the text with you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can take turns reading each stanza.
Prompt students to find all the words with variant vowel
spellings in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. Point out that the title asks a question.
Explain that students will read two opinions about this statement: Water should be free for everyone. Ask students to think about which side they agree with.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
views about the best way to stop pollution.
: When was a time when you and a friend had
views about something? What did you do?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names something in our homes that can leak water. (faucets)
Why does the boy think water should be free? Find sentences that answer this question.
How can you tell the girl has an
or opposite, view? What reasons does she give to support her argument?
Which side presented a more convincing argument? Why do you think this?
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with variant vowel
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 3 (period), 4 (question mark), and 10 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text lists ways that water becomes polluted. It includes a diagram with labels and arrows. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title slowly, syllable by syllable, and then blend the syllables to say the word. Have students repeat. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a fairy tale about a character who can change straw into gold.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means feeling lost and without hope.
Example: Dad looked for his lost phone in
What is something that might make you feel
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what the girl must use to make gold. (straw)
What does the small man offer to do? What must the girl give him in return? Find the sentences that answer the questions.
What two events cause the girl to be filled with
, or hopelessness? How does she overcome each problem?
What other fairy tales have you read or heard? Which story is your favorite? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that a legend is a story from the past that has been passed down over time. It is often about someone who really lived, but the facts of that persons life in the story cant be proven true. Explain that this legend features three birds instead of people: a hawk, a crow, and an eagle. Name and describe each bird and have students point to it in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means acting in a polite way, or showing respect for others.
to keep your mouth closed when you eat, and cover your nose when you sneeze.
: What are some ways you are
? How do you feel when people around you are not being
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what Crow and Hawk are doing that makes so much noise. (squawking)
How can you tell Crow and Hawk are arguing? Find the words and phrases that answer the question.
How can you tell Crow and Hawk are
, or polite, way? How does Eagle show them how to act with respect toward each other?
What rules do we have at school to remind us to be
? Why is it important to treat each other with respect?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
